body: @kchibisov Sounds like keyboard protocol stuff? This seems intentional on kakoune's end.
I think it's due to kakoune really wanting associated text, I'll try to write a patch.

issue.title: Send associated text for shifted numbers with kitty

body:
>ctrl + [ does not trigger ESC-equivalent behaviour in kakoune. 

This is not an escape when you have kitty protocol, so unless kakoune explicitly binds it won't work.

>alt + K (keep not matching), alt + N (extend reverse search).

Not sure what they supposed to do, we reported them the same as in other terminals when kitty protocol is in use.

@kchibisov 

> This should probably fix the `alt + shift + 1`

`alt + shift + 1` does not work with and without a patch.

before:
```
[325.781451523s] [TRACE] [alacritty_terminal] Setting title to 'Some("*scratch* 4:2 [scratch] 1 sel - client0@[18589] - Kakoune")'
[325.781533218s] [TRACE] [alacritty_terminal] Setting private mode: SyncUpdate
[325.781563469s] [TRACE] [alacritty_terminal] Unsetting private mode: SyncUpdate
[325.781586171s] [TRACE] [alacritty_terminal] Unsetting private mode: SyncUpdate
[325.781608326s] [TRACE] [alacritty_terminal] Going to: line=3, col=4
```

after:
```
[16.494565079s] [TRACE] [alacritty_terminal] Setting title to 'Some("*scratch* 1:1 [scratch] 1 sel - client0@[20513] - Kakoune")'
[16.494646028s] [TRACE] [alacritty_terminal] Setting private mode: SyncUpdate
[16.494674332s] [TRACE] [alacritty_terminal] Unsetting private mode: SyncUpdate
[16.494696849s] [TRACE] [alacritty_terminal] Unsetting private mode: SyncUpdate
[16.494718592s] [TRACE] [alacritty_terminal] Going to: line=0, col=3
```


> but I'm not sure what could happen with `ctrl + [` or `alt + K`, they work the same compared to e.g. kitty/foot when I look into the generated events.

With `ctrl + [` you're actually right. `alacritty <0.13` matches the behaviour of eg. `xterm` or `gnome-terminal` and not `foot`/`kitty` and there it works. I guess it's because of the protocol you've mentioned although I'm not familiar with it to understand all the implications. Could you elaborate a little bit more? Can it be tweaked/turned off? Manual binding seems to solve it

FTR:
```
# Bind ^[ to ESC everywhere
map global insert <c-[> <esc>
map global normal <c-[> <esc>
map global prompt <c-[> <esc>
map global menu <c-[> <esc>
map global user <c-[> <esc>
map global goto <c-[> <esc>
map global view <c-[> <esc>
map global object <c-[> <esc>
```

but muscle memory is going to be annoying on vanilla editor configurations :( Feels like [1172](https://xkcd.com/1172/) case.

However, `alt + K`, `alt + !`, `alt + shift + /`, `alt + N` etc. seems to work correctly & same in `kitty`, `foot`, `xterm`, `gnome-terminal` and `alacritty pre-0.13` but not on master.

Could you not truncate the logs output and tell me exactly what to do in kakoune?

>map global menu <c-[> <esc>

Just remap it in alacritty if you want to emit the `chars` you need, no need to alter editor here.

I just tried `kak` myself which I can install on fedora, and `alt+k` doesn't work for me in both kitty, foot, alacritty. `kak` enabled the `DISAMBIGUATE` and `REPORT_ALT_TEXT`, to simulate what it's doing, you should try running 

```
printf "\e[=5;1u" && showkey -a
```

Then when you press `Alt + k` you should see something like

```
^[[107;3u 	 27 0033 0x1b
```

The same I see in foot, and kitty adds the my base layout information along the way, which is irrelevant for this case.

I thought initially that kak uses base keys, thus I wrote a patch to account for `!` -> `1` relationship, however for the `alt+k` there's no such a thing, meaning that the issue on the `kak` side, which is unfortunate.

On the other part, nvim and vim itself, both enable the same mods and work just fine, as you've seen.

Ah, no, it actually works in all alacritty,kitty,foot for me, I just haven't figured out how it should work, since you need to press `ESC` first and then `alt+k`, because you need to enter normal? mode. If I enter some normal? mode and then press `alt+k` it works as it should, pre 0.13 I just had to press it twice, because first one will emit `esc` and thus make me into the normal mode?, so I was testing it differently.
Could you try with the `alacritty --config-file /dev/null` config actually, maybe you have conflicting encoding in your bindings and that's why it doesn't work?

`kakoune` is a modal editor, so yes, normal mode is expected for `alt + k` or `alt + K` to work. Sorry, should have been more clear on that.

`alt + k` works just fine in the new alacritty version, I just meant  the keybindings with `alt + shift` in them, so `alt + shift + k` - thus `alt + K`. The same goes for `alt + !` because `alt + shift + 1`.

So expected behaviour (normal mode):
- `alt + k`: see "keep matching".
- `alt + shift + k`: see "keep not matching". (does NOT work in 0.13)
- `/`: see "search"
- `alt + /`: see "reverse search"
- `shift + /`: see "search (extend)"
- `alt + shift + /`: see "reverse search (extend)". (does NOT work in 0.13)
- `!`: see "insert output"
- `alt + !`: see "append output". (does NOT work in 0.13)

From comparing different key bindings seems like `shift` is ignored as soon as `alt` is pressed. So pressing `alt + shift + /` yields "reverse search" which is bound to `alt + /`.

My config is quite bare-bone. `--config-file /dev/null` yields no change in behaviour :/

Ah, ok.

This should fix it https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/pull/7493

FTR, I sshed into the Ubuntu based box and everything seems to work on ancient `kakoune v2020.09.01` that they ship, including `ctrl + [`. I'm using `kakoune v2023.07.29`. I don't know which version they ship on Fedora. Even more variables in the equation unfortunately :/

> This should fix it https://github.com/alacritty/alacritty/pull/7493

I'll check now, thanks for a quick feedback :)
Patch seems to fix the issue with the `alt + shift`  I'm still wondering why in the old kakoune `ctrl + [` works just fine, very curious.

`ctrl + [` is just escape, however kitty protocol tries to _solve_ this issue and make it distinguishable from `ESC`.

And just thinking about it you can't really solve it with alacritty binding...

> `ctrl + [` is just escape, however kitty protocol tries to _solve_ this issue and make it distinguishable from `ESC`.
> 
> And just thinking about it you can't really solve it with alacritty binding...

@kchibisov 
Initially I interpreted your comment as you keep working on getting the `^[` to work but considering that you closed the issue I assume that on `alacritty` part everything works as intended? Because PR merged into the master does not make `^[` trigger `ESC` action in `kakoune`. Sorry for the confusion.
